Comment: Not to be too anal, but you mean VPSO (Village Public Safety Officer), not VSPO. And I believe Wassillie, the victim, was a VPO (Village Police Officer), not a VPSO. There is a big difference. A VPSO goes through state training & is recognized & supervised & paid by the state. There are way more VPOs than VPSOs. VPOs get a lot less training, & none of it is from the state that I know of. VPOs get lower pay, & VPOs are not officially recognized by the state due to the state's  opposition to tribal sovereignty. VPOs are paid & supervised by tribal councils. VPOs have high turnover & are often very young guys. VPSOs are meant to be a career option & have longer term professionals, generally. Both jobs are very tough & involve putting yourself in danger without a gun. High stress & low pay. Lots of alcohol-fueled domestic disputes, sometimes relatives. 

And to #3, yes the booze came from Bethel, the only hub here. The villages all vote to be dry but BET lets it pour in & profits from it.

Comment: Peeing in the park/alley when you think no one is looking is not an offense that requires registration as a sex offender in the State of Colorado. It does not meet the elements of Indecent Exposure, which requires a KNOWING exposure of genitals to the view of another person when done with the intent to arouse. It also does not meet the elements of Public Indecency (which only requires registration after a second conviction within 5 years), which requires a KNOWING exposure of genitals to the view of another person.

Also, the juvenile sex offender registry is not made available to the public in the same way as the adult sex offender registry. And first-time juvenile sex offenders are able to petition for de-registration once they have successfully completed their sentence.

Comment: Many Asian women did indeed provide “comfort” services to the Japanese Imperial Forces during World War II, but I do not believe they did it at the point of a gun nor was it sexual slavery.    Throughout history, military forces have had no problem finding “comfort women” regardless of the country in which they operated and they were able to find them without kidnapping, coercion or threats of any kind.  Wars create horrible conditions which cause people to resort to often unthinkable means to survive.  For many women, it was the use of their bodies, and there usually was more supply than demand.  I personally witness this during the Korean War and during two years in Vietnam.  Some members of the Imperial Japanese forces no doubt forced women to have sex, which, of course, is rape, but I believe the “comfort women” who served the Imperial Japanese forces in brothels that sprung up and operated near Japanese bases did so voluntarily for pay.

Comment: Mokantx, quick note.

The "Instructions for Diocesan Synods" issued by the Cong. for Bishops and the Cong. for the Evangelization of Peoples goes to great pains to make clear that the bishop governs.  Quotes:

The purpose of the diocesan Synod is to assist the Bishop in the exercise of the office proper to him, namely, that of governing the Christian community.

This purpose determines the particular roles to be ascribed to those priests who partake in the work of the Synod "as wise collaborators with the Order of Bishops, their helpers and chosen instruments, and who are called to serve the People of God"[5]. The Synod also offers the Bishop the opportunity of calling to cooperate with him and with his priests some members of the laity as well as some chosen religious.

Thus any attempt to place the Synod in opposition to the Bishop on the grounds of "representation of the People of God" is contrary to the authentic order of ecclesial relations.

I am not looking for any “terminology”.  Certainly not the irrelevant mess you’ve posted here.  I simply post facts which I can and do, support with valid evidence upon request.
.
Fluoride is the anion of the element fluorine.  An anion is a negatively charged atom.  One such atom of fluorine is identical to all other such atoms of fluorine, regardless the source compound from which they are released.  This is just elementary chemistry.
.
The only substances ingested as a result of fluoridation are fluoride ions, identical to those fluoride ions which have always existed in water, and trace contaminants in barely detectable amounts far below EPA mandated maximum allowable levels of safety. 
.
The US CDC estimates that 75% of daily fluoride intake in the US is from water and beverages.  

Steven D. Slott, DDS

Comment: The President cannot be charged with obstruction of justice under normal criminal law standards, but he can be impeached if Congress determines that what he did fits the broad Constitutional definition of impeachable offenses. One example is Nixon and Watergate. Nixon obstructed justice by refusing to turnover the Watergate tapes but he was not arrested and charged with that offense. He was impeached for it. Impeachment is a constitutional check and balance between the President and Congress. Nixon resigned before being tried by the US Senate where he would have been found guilty. Impeachment and not some Federal statute, is why Trump has put so much explaining into the question of why he fired Comey and whether it had anything to do with the investigation of Trump associates.

Comment: cont:  They will fall further and further behind as they move through succeeding years.  Schools often provide remedial "tutoring" to help.  But, receiving such tutoring precludes being in the "regular" class as it moves forward, and a student seldom really "catches" up.  Summer sessions may be helpful to avoid this issue.  

However, regular class teachers are "forced" to gear their teaching to the needs of the students in the class.  Realistically (and problematically) this usually means teaching at or near the "lowest common denominator" of the class.  Ability grouping, which is opposed by many as "discriminatory", can address this issue.  However, this means a portion of students will move "faster and further" than those in a "lower" ability group.  

IMO, we need to move beyond the idea that each year kids will "advance together" and, instead, have students move forward based on their development, not their chronological age.  ..would enjoy visiting w/you on this one   Gary

Comment: Towering, You and Charles and I can agree on only one oil tax concept. We should base our tax on the gross (not net) per barrel market price. The policy should be so simple that anyone Andy Josephson included can easily understand it. A simple dependable tax everyone can plan on until the oil is gone. State and Federal regulations must not discriminate against small oil producers that increase competition. Good government is government that never needs changed. Plan ahead you can count on it to be as it is.

Comment: Actually, Fairchild Field is not an issue for corporate jet aircraft. Even the largest ones can handle a precision instrument approach to Runway 8. That runway is nearly 7000 feet. Runway 26 (opposite direction same runway) has a displaced threshold (due to the trees) reducing it to 5000 feet visual approach, but that's still plenty for most jets. Jet A fuel is available all day, and after hours with a phone call.

Those trees are planned to come down which will allow the displaced threshold to be removed. 

The huge 747-sized freighters could never use Fairchild without completely new runways that are strengtened to SeaTac standards. That would be a hundreds of millions of dollars proposition. However, the runways are in good shape per their design and can handle 115,000 pound aircraft, so small freighters can operate now (737 class). Remember that this was a fighter base back with it was an Air Force Base, and the runways were built VERY well for medium and small aircraft.

Comment: It's not entirely correct that the O-line is preventing Trevor Siemian from being a good NFL starting QB.  True, the O-line is a huge problem.  However, so is Siemian's decision making.  Whether he's throwing balls to receivers who are well covered, or scrambling into pressure, Trevor is as much of a problem as the O-line.  If opposing defenses stack the box with 7 or 8 dudes, it's up to Trevor to throw them out of that defense.  He has to get rid of the ball quicker and more accurately.  If he can't do that, then it doesn't matter who is playing on the O-line.  He's as much to blame, if not slightly more, than the O-line.

Comment: Our overall fertility rate is is around 1.5 which is similar to other developed countries, which means we are rapidly approaching the point where there will be more deaths then births. Hence the continued push toward increasing immigration. The sticking point is what type of immigration is most needed in this country, and balancing it with existing jobs, and also building towards the future. Bringing in relatively young skilled workers is the goal of every country, and often the competition is high, as other developed nations are facing the same problem. The Conservatives need to tailor their immigration policy, to fit the needs of the country now and in the future. Which means that while we will still deal with refugees, we have to be more practical and selective when we are opening the doors to immigration. Immigration should be viewed the same way as, healthcare, infrastructure or anything else government does. Does it make sense, and will it benefit the country.

Comment: How does a Muslim woman quietly riding a public bus create any harm, or risk of harm, to the broader public good? She doesn't. 

Would the author draw the same conclusion if for “Muslim woman” in the above extract we substitute “person wearing a KKK hood”.

I suspect he might not. And, presumably, it would be on the grounds that KKK garb is a potent symbol of a racist ideology. And, as such, the wearing of it in public  does create at least the risk of harm in a society that professes to abhor racism in all its forms. 

Surely, there is a parallel argument that garb that conceals a woman's face is a potent symbol of a misogynistic mentality that cannot be tolerated in a country that proclaims the equality of men and women. 

So I suggest, with respect to the author, that there is indeed an argument that women who go about their business with their face masked do create a risk of harm to the broader public good.

Comment: Thanks, I was ignorant of the paint color rationale. I was reminded of the controversy re Mt. Rushmore. And, yes, this is a clash, call it culture, call it esthetics, call it nature vs. industrialization. Maybe now this clash which has been brewing for quite a while has reached a tipping point. I doubt it is the end of astronomical science if the TMT goes quietly away. I can remember being on the mountain top in 1970 and seeing piles of scrap metal and waste in a depression behind some of the structures and thinking it a paradox that this remarkable place with its great potential to aid scientific investigation had been uglified sort of an arrogance of science.

Comment: Phone records, including text messages, can be retrieved from the issuing phone companies with a court order during discovery phase with narrow parameters such as only text or phone messages between the 2 parties with the wave of a judge's pen. You can delete all of the texts you want off the phone itself but anything sent across cellular is maintained on the phone company servers, including pictures. Even deleting the texts is no guarantee that they can't be retrieved, even on an encrypted phone.  
My guess is the state will settle out of court with no admission of wrongdoing and no disciplinary actions, hence, no name of the trooper in the article but likely it will appear if an actual lawsuit is filed.

Comment: Not a bad reflection.

Patriotism is a virtue, a strength, love for one's country.

Some on the right have 'shallowed' its meaning; most on the left simply demean even the idea of patriotism. 

It's rooted in the 4th Commandment, as the CCC tell us.   It's an extension of love for our parents. 

There is no love without sacrifice.  If you haven't sacrificed well for your country, you cannot love it.

Sacrifice doesn't mean military service, or combat service; it can certainly mean this.

But sacrifice can also mean raising one's children very well so that they learn what it means to love (sacrifice, self-denial, selflessness, constancy & cheerfulness of gift of self). 

So that the children learn how to be "big minded, good hearted, and strong living" (generous, constructive-minded, not fragile sorts focused on the self). 

We have generations of people who haven't learned how to love in this most Christian way, and who have raised whole families who have no idea what I am saying.

Comment: Drug trials should be sequestered and not carried out by those who wish to profit from them.

The marketing of pharmaceuticals should also be severely constrained.  it is interesting to note that press releases, newspaper articles and advertisements always show the relative ratio and not the absolute benefit, absolute risk and numbers needed to treat.  The relative ratio inflates benefit and when given alone does not give a complete picture of a drugs efficacy.  It would be easy for the government to mandate that full information be given on prescription monographs but I suppose the industry wouldn't tolerate that.

Health Canada has set a very low bar for approving pharmaceuticals; post approval follow-up is weak, and it is virtually impossible to find the absolute risk and the absolute benefit of any of the drugs listed on their site thus making informed prescribing difficult for both the medical professional and for the patient.

Comment: A rental contract is not a "lease."  Oregon law, to my knowledge, still allows either party in a month-to-month rental contract to terminate that contract with a 30 day notification.  The conversations I've both read and heard refer to a "no-cause eviction".  To my knowledge, there is no such process.......There is, indeed, a FED (Forcible Entry and Detainer) eviction process for a landlord to regain control of his/her rental - lease property.  This process is separate from a contract termination.  The Portland Ordinance effectively eliminates a landlord's ability to terminate a month-to-month rental agreement/contract. I'm guessing such action will be successfully challenged by landlord/property owners in Portland.  It should be.   Gary (been a landlord for 30 years) Crum

Comment: You understand that volcanic activity of a very specific sort (large eruptions that inject large amounts of aerosols into the upper atmosphere, preferably in the tropics) is about the only kind that impacts the climate system in a significant way. The most recent eruption of this type was Pinatubo, in 1991. The problem for you is that volcanic events like these *cool* the climate, and only for a few years, at most. We have observed a sustained increase in global average temperature for decades now. Volcanic activity cannot explain that.

Comment: And you wonder why retail managers, at many stores, have to approve voids while you wait...

This has been an issue at many retail stores.  It is not a unique happening.

It's hard to imagine, that this store's computers didn't put out regular reports of void activity by checker that would have warned the store manager - or even distant corporate accounting personnel - that there was a problem.

We are talking a lot of theft here.

Comment: "Eliminating Grade 13 was a huge mistake. The vast majority of students entering University these days are massively ill-prepared. "

That's because there's this bias in high schools that university is the only pathway to a high-paying job. And instead of thinking outside the box and challenging this idea, many students choose to lock themselves in and throw away the key, not knowing how much of a painstaking commitment university can be.

Of course, the same can be said for community college, apprenticeships and "entry-level" workplace jobs. But right now, university seems to be the silver bullet according to most graduates.

And Grade 13 isn't the solution for this-a more challenging curriculum, which rigorously tests students' abilities, is.

Source: I'm a recent Ontario high-school graduate.

Comment: I can't speak for the author making the claim, but I would imagine that they're not saying absolute demand for condos is weak (which would result in unsold inventory, which we clearly have not seen), but rather RELATIVE demand is weaker compared to the market for detached houses.

However, comparing the graphs in price increases since 2001 (see here: bit.ly/2qcrzaJ )… I can't see any clear evidence for that claim. Median prices of detached houses appear to be ~1.7x higher than condo prices in 2001, and while both markets grew substantially, the ratio of prices looks about the same in 2013.

But since the data is 4 years old, it's possible that things have changed since then, and detached house prices have really taken off.

Comment: That's not only difficult, but it's borderline impossible under existing law. Since officers are hired and not elected like sheriff's in the Lower 48, the selection process may fall under a "personnel action" heading, which automatically makes a lot of it confidential.

What may be possible is for more communities and their police departments to form citizen advisory councils with their police departments. This is a group of private citizens, usually community leaders, who meet regularly and provide advice to the Chief of Police on affairs between the community and the public. These folks can also receive more training in how police actually conduct business than we can ever give the general public, and they're great for improving police-community relations, because when something happens, they're not speaking as officers, but as educated people that are trusted by the community.

Comment: I agree with you ATF. Back when I was prosecuting white-collar fraud cases, it was almost impossible to get a long prison sentence even when the fraud involved millions of dollars. In one case, I had to appeal the judge's sentencing decision TWICE to get him to follow the sentencing guidelines. He held that against me for the rest of my career. Federal district judges don;t like it when you take them up for a spanking by an appellate court. The case involved a very nice white businessman with a nice pretty wife and four nice well-kept children.  I actually wrote in the brief to the appellate court that the probationary sentence on this, a several-million-dollar fraud case, gave the appearance that we have one system for the nice, white, and wealthy and another for the poor and black. It was a sincere argument. The very conservative (back then) Fourth Circuit agreed. On remand, the district judge again refused to sentence properly. Another appeal. Won again, at a price.

JP II wrote in Laborem exercens, "Besides wages, various social benefits intended to ensure the life and health of workers and their families play a part here. Yet there are conservative Catholics -- hello, Paul Ryan -- who say that healthcare is a privilege.

JPII, in Centesimus Annus, 30-31 wrote “‘man should not consider his material possessions as his own, but as common to all,’ because ‘above the laws and judgments of men stands the law, the judgment of Christ. Comment: I've only lived in Anchorage for five years- but I've noticed a big change in that short time. There seem to be a lot of unsolved murders here, but maybe the percentage is similar to other cities. You can see read about some of them on the Anchorage Crime Stoppers website. In April of 2012 there was a murder in my neighborhood, someone shot two men in the R&R Garage in broad daylight. One died. It is still unsolved. And they never solved the murder of Aylett Hanson either. Now we have another instance of two people being murdered on the trail system. (My neighbors and I heard gunshots that night not long before the bodies were found so I'm presuming the victims were shot). I've never experienced a police department that kept things this close to the vest before. No police scanner, no valuable information being shared with the anxious public, nothing. Just a reminder to avoid isolated areas at night. I really don't feel good about the way they are handling this.

Comment: Alceste, my father was raised on a farm (born 1920) and there is a wonderful picture of him and his brother both around 5 with beautiful long flowing hair. Wearing shorts. Comment: No, just natural realities.

We get sick, we have headaches and sores, we get terminal illness.

The question is:  Have you learned how to sanctify all the realities that God allows in your life?

Here's one:  People make silly or cutting or sarcastic remarks for various reasons and deficiencies.   

Well formed Catholics say: It's our own defects that make us unhappy. I refuse to let this person's small or cutting or cynical or snide remarks dampen my cheer at all.  I am an adopted and loved child of God. Nothing can shake my joy.  God is my Father after all.

And so rather than getting sad or upset when someone makes a small or sarcastic or cutting remark, the well formed Catholic simply integrates this experience with the suffering that Jesus happily took on for us.  

We unite our suffering with us, and we are joyful because of this intimacy we share with Joy Himself.

Comment: Western woods: Irony is often employed as a form of satire, which of course is often employed as a form of humor. The upper-case "L" in Liberal in the context of the more general proposition constitutes a double irony, which is in its own right a legitimate literary or rhetorical device.  Use of a lower-case "l" could have been interpreted to convey either a factual or a singularly ironic meaning, depending on the reader's point of view, rendering the upper-case usage an inherently more clever strategy.

Comment: A dentist should go where the patients are, that's their calling, to serve their patients. Comment: The "New" International Market Place seems to be following a noted pattern in retail in this town, similar to that of Ala Moana and, even closer, the Waikiki Trade Center. Simply put, the dynamics of what these places were to us in our youth have completely changed as the quirkiness yields to maximum income per sq.ft. 

One observation I will make is the fact that IMP, AMC and even smaller venues such as Pearlridge seem to be angling not so much for the local buyer, but for a pan-pacific buyer. It seems to me that all of the bigger retail establishments are moving Honolulu to be like the Paris of the Pacific. While Paris is the shopping capitol of Europe, and Hong Kong still reigns, it seems with these developments that Hawaii is trying to become a similar magnet for the Pacific region south, west and north of the islands (with us yielding the mainland to that of Los Angeles, San Francisco and such).

Comment: Carpo,
That's exactly the way a mortgage is supposed to work. Properly constructed mortgages are good deals that are designed to address violations by one side or the other.
If, on the other hand, you "violated the terms of your agreement" (for example, did not make your payments), and the agreement had NOT been properly structured to allow foreclosure by the bank, that would be an example of a BAD deal for the bank.
IOW, it's equally possible to be in violation of a GOOD deal as it is to be in violation of a BAD deal. The act of violating a deal does not mean the deal is good OR bad.

Best,

RTD

Comment: This is a US based article and it may have a slightly different connotation south of the border.   In jobs where tips are earned, the employer can pay less than minimum wage.   Some 20 states pay a "tipping wage" of $2.13 per hour.   The goal is to ensure the employees wages make it to the state's minimum wage, with tips.   In the US your tip can be making up a significant portion of that server's  wage.

Hoteliers are trying hard to get patrons to tip  cleaners.  This will eventually allow them to reduce the Chamber cleaners wages to a 'tipping wage".  Nice, eh? 

I do see tips being requested almost everywhere.  I ignore them most of the time.   I do not tip when I buy take-out food.  I tip cabs, my barber and I tip a minimum of 15% and rarely more than 20% when I sit down to eat.

Comment: "Dithering" is not the word I would use. Dallaire told Trudeau and Sajjan last year not to go to Mali, so they didn't go, despite all the indicators to allies they would. But Mali, of all the missions in Africa, still makes the most sense for a host of reasons. But it only makes sense if there is more to the commitment than just showing up to say "Canada is back.". 

Mali has long been a close developmental partner of Canada (for decades). Mali has deeper problems beyond the tiny group of extremists in the north. Most of the armed groups in the north and centre of the country have real grievances about the way the country is run. The 2015 peace agreement is flawed. Canada has to go in with eyes open and not defer to France or Algeria on political questions. That is the problem: Trudeau wants low risk, high profile. Mali needs moderate risk-taking, engaged partners. Canada could be that parnter, but so far PMO/PCO/DND/GAC do not provide any confidence there is any strategic plan.

Comment: As one who has hiked Haiku stairs several times and lives beneath it, I support keeping it open. While hiking the stairs, it would be common to pass 50 - 100 hikers going the opposite direction. The aloha would be to have the more confident hiker move to the side and allow the others to pass freely. There are also multiple landings for breaks and passing one another. This is certainly not a problem and should not be thought of as a reason for closure. However, I would recommend ensuring that all hikers take responsibility for themselves and understand that the hike is challenging. Parking is not an issue as many take the bus or park on streets below Haiku village.

Comment: twy4Dolphin: I happen to agree that not just Eugene but Oregon depends far too much on income and property taxes and would be better served to have a sales tax. But every time Oregon has tried to go there, the idea has been soundly defeated by voters. And there is no way for Eugene to unilaterally adopt a sales tax. Voting “no” on Ballot Measure 20-275 wouldn’t result in a sales tax to fix our streets. It will just result in more potholes and eventually more streets falling into disrepair, as we had back in 2008 when voters *demanded* the City of Eugene fix the streets. And over time, we would just end up having to pay more to fix streets we let deteriorate.

If you drive on our streets—or ride a bus, or bicycle or walk—vote “yes” to keep our streets in good repair!

Comment: Such good memories of mango trees. I remember when people with Mango trees used to set out bags of these delicious foods on the sidewalk for anyone to take, or leave them on their stone walls for whoever wanted one. I miss that! I hardly ever see that happening any more. One of the things I remember best about Mangos is the sound and sensation of them falling on a tin roof in the middle of the night! Loud enough to rouse anyone from a sound sleep. I think most people are just too lazy to rake up the leaves and so their solution is to cut the down the tree, forgetting that they also provide valuable shade which will be much needed as temperatures continue to climb. I don't know about the influence of bees but seems strange that the mango tree I planted bloomed for the first time this year but only had 1 mango on it. Of course the wind caused some loss of our avos and ulu but don't know what happened with with our mango tree. The other tree I really miss are the smell-good plumeria.

Comment: Our tribe had always had a form of Justice, long before the Europeans, Spanish, Mexicans and Americans came into the Southwest. The histories of the Southwest tribes vary depending on the tribe but all had some form of government and consequences for whoever violated tribal code. When the U.S. took over, the Federal government established a government to government relationship with the 19 Pueblos in New Mexico. To signify this relationship and acknowledge their governments, President Abraham Lincoln sent silver headed canes to each of the Pueblo governors. Over the years, the traditional form of governments have been "tweeted" to reflect or incorporate parts of some of the Spanish,Mexican,and American governments who invaded the Southwest. When New Mexico became a territory of the United States the tribes incorporated parts of what they wanted or needed of the American system into their tribal government. No state money goes to Pueblo tribes. Many of the tribes now are self-sufficient

Unless he has three hands, two to collect water and one to hold the gun, and three eyeballs, one for what his two hands are doing and two for binocular vision to correctly gauge distance and position, I don't see how a gun would have helped here. In fact the two eyeballs would have to be in the side or back of his head. (And maybe extra brains to do two things at once). 

Bottom line is if you are solo, a gun or a bear spray is a false sense of security. You have no security. Even with two people, a gun would be difficult to use effectively entangled with your buddy "in dense brush". 

Making a lot of noise is just something people feel ridiculous doing, as far as I can tell, but I think it might have helped.

Comment: You fail to respond to the point mentioning that those most needing relief will be the ones receiving it.  

You focus on the calamitous impact of the fifty cent raise.  In Oregon only 5% of the work force in the state work for that $9.25/hour minimum wage.  Additionally, most of them work part time, mainly because keeping hours "short", usually less that 30 per week, allows employers to avoid paying any benefits.  So we're actually talking about, at the most, a 5% increase for 5% of the workforce.  This will hardly jeopardize Oregon's economy.  Also remember labor cost represent only a portion of a busiess's overhead.  Indeed, some businesses will use this minimum wage increase as an "excuse" to raise their prices, but be aware that the actual increase in the cost of doing business will, for those companies impacted at all (most will not be), likely will be  less than than one percent.

Comment: Democrat1: The Nuremberg principle applies to war crimes. While the International Court of Justice ruled in the 90s that use of nuclear weapons in war would likely violate humanitarian laws, no nuclear-capable state accepts this ruling. And in particular, people who personally believe that use of nuclear weapons is necessarily a war crime would be unlikely to be put in the position of ever having to execute an order to use them.

So while it is theoretically plausible that people in the chain of command for a nuclear strike would be liable, in practice nobody would ever be prosecuted. Notably, the same applies even if your country is already under a nuclear attack and you are responding proportionately -- this wouldn't make it any more or less a war crime. But the capability for that response to be unquestionably carried out was critically important during the Cold War.

Comment: John A. Parker - You have ZERO understanding of how market-based economics work. The price of any good or service is driven by the price the customer is willing to pay. If customers refuse to buy gasoline at $4 an gallon, the supply chain is forced to adjust its prices downward if they hope to sell gasoline. When new competition entered the market and increased the supply, it drove the cost of oil down, which drove the price at the pump down.

In medicine, doctors, pharmacies, labs, hospitals, etc., charge what "the market will bear", which is currently the insurance company reimbursement schedule, plus 20% for the copayment. Take the insurance companies out of the middle and medical providers are forced to negotiate price with the consumer, who can choose between competing providers or,forego some medical treatment, which drives the costs downward. "What the market will bear" changes dramatically and thus changes the prices.

Comment: Before retiring I flew between Southeast to Anchorage and other points further North. Lots of us regulars use to get to the boarding gate early to let them know we would be happy to give up our seat if needed because Alaska use to offer free tickets/vouchers and other goodies. 
I was on a flight once where we got stuck in Petersburg on a Sunday night do to a broken plane. We had our rooms paid for, meal vouchers and even telephone cards to call home on.
Last few years I have only been flying South for medical reasons or for family reasons. Alaska has been fantastic 100% of the time ! 
I hate it when I have to fly on another airline. After being away from home, boarding Alaska is like being home. 
When my son was in the Marine Corp, he was treated like a hero by the flight crew when he came home. They always went the extra mile to help insure he made it back to San Diego in time to get to his base.
I wrote United and suggested they could learn from Alaska how to treat passengers.

Comment: No inheritance tax?   Hardly.  It's there, it's significant and it goes by other names. 

To start with, in Ontario there is roughly 1.5% probate tax payable immediately, upon the entire value of the estate, just to file the will.   

Then the remainder of the estate is taxed as if it were income, which in Ontario will be 53.53% if the remainder exceeds $220,000, which is not particularly high, especially if the deceased had to fund their own retirement.  

So the government is already taking almost 55% of what should rightfully be going to the beneficiaries of the estate, whether it's kids/grandkids or a charity. 

Just how much more does the author think is 'fair'?

Comment: "When you take this quantitative relation into account, you discover that there is a physical uncertainty that comes out. But it isn't an uncertainty in measuring both variables together, but in each variable. In particular, what you learn is that you always have an uncertainty in position (Δx), and you always have an uncertainty in momentum (Δp), no matter how accurately you measure either one. Moreover, the product of those uncertainties (ΔxΔp) must always be greater than or equal to ℏ/2. It's impossible to know any quantity that obeys this quantum relation to an arbitrary accuracy."

Comment: And I was telling you when you have things closer together like that, you suffer with future expansion.  It works on a small airport like the examples I gave you because they don't need to handle a ton of passengers.  But it doesn't work if you're an airport that's projected to grow from 31M pax/year (when DIA opened in 1995) to 80M in a few decades.  Thank goodness DIA was built with a design that does allow for such expansion, rather than one of the "everything close-in" designs that suffer from lack of expansion capacity.  

Yes, you have to walk a little more.  Yes, you have to take a few escalators (I'm still puzzled as to why that's supposedly a bad thing).  Yes, you have to take a (rather efficient) train between concourses.  But what do we get for such minor inconveniences?... a very effective, roomy airport that now handles 53M with relative ease and the ability to expand to 80M.

https://www.flydenver.com/den20/then_now

Comment: This report is a clear reminder of the importance of recruiting in college sports, especially in a big team sport like football. And how critical it is to the long term success of a program. The two most important tasks for any head coach are player recruitment and development -- they go hand in hand. All the more reason that the Ducks success on the field is a big (though not the only) determinative factor in which recruits decide to commit and which don't. That may all sound more like high-stakes big business than what college or university sports played by amateur athletes should be about, but (rightly or wrongly) that's the fundamental reality of intercollegiate athletics in 2016.

Comment: "Although my evidence is anecdotal"
That's another word for "useless". 
We can't base policy interventions on anecdotal evidence, we can't base it on emotions, we need to base it on numbers.
Fact is - you are probably - by virtue of your social circle, race, income and status MUCH more likely to KNOW farmers who were murdered and not very likely to know victims of township murders.
"People I know" is decidedly NOT a representative sample.  You can't conclude anything whatsoever from that.

The fact is, that the vast majority of South Africa's murders happen in the townships. The fact is that the single biggest thing we can do to make the country safer is to massively increase police presence in the townships.
That's where the bulk of the problem lies. 
When we've solved that - when we've PICKED the low hanging fruit -THEN we can allocate resources to farm murders. White's are only 1.8% of murder victims (for 10% of the population) and farmers only a small fraction of that 1.8%.

Comment: Normally, I'm quicker than most to get outraged when the City adds yet another regressive fixed base charge to every household, rich and poor alike.  But this time, I think the new charge is both moderate and very sensible.

If the City loses its current fire insurance rating, as it definitely will if we don't fix staffing, we will all pay a much bigger $ penalty than this in insurance premium hikes (which also get passed on in rent increases).  Adding four good local jobs, which will feed our economy while it makes our community safer, just makes sense.  And it's cheap at the price.

It's also important to remember that when any major catastrophe happens, it's the Fire Department that bears the brunt of rescuing people from cave-ins, dealing with hazmat incidents, treating the injured and getting them to hospital  --  I'm saying that this is not a good function to economize on.  We need these guys.

Comment: We have been consuming resources since the beginning of civilization, and yet there are more of us around. Intelligent use of resources (e.g., replacing gas guzzlers with more efficient Japanese cars in the 1970s) has made consumption more sustainable.

Housing is not expensive because of immigration. If it was, there should have been a bigger housing bubble today in the US (since it has more immigrants today) than in 2008. It was due to low interest money floating around in the system.

Once we start considering euthanasia because we are a burden to others, it will not be long before caregivers start thinking the elderly a burden too. Ageism is already an issue in health care and "bed-blockers" are spoken of quite disparagingly by some health care staff. How long before they start "suggesting" euthanasia? And how long before people make the decision based on finances? 

The original paper on euthanasia in 1922 talked about "lives not worthy of living." By the end of WWII 265 hospitals in Germany were practising euthanasia, with the death rate in some psychiatric facilities being over 25%

Comment: There appears to be a lot of confusion between "nicotine" and "smoking." They are not the same thing. Smoking involves setting something (in this case, tobacco) on fire and inhaling the resulting smoke. Smoke from any source can be hazardous to health, because the tar that's produced can clog up the lungs, the carbon monoxide damages the heart and circulatory system, and the numerous chemicals of combustion can cause a variety of cancers. None of these elements are present in vapor because vapor isn't smoke. So Rep. Pollet is incredibly mistaken when he refers to incredible damage to people's health. Nicotine is a stimulant that's about as harmful as caffeine. Both should probably be avoided by someone with a serious heart condition, but can prove quite helpful to those without such a problem. Both can improve mood, alertness, and concentration which explains why smoking is so hard to quit. Vaping saves lives by providing the nicotine sans the garbage delivered by smoke.

Comment: Trump could resign before his term is over, but I doubt his ego would allow that because he knows it would be interpreted as an admission that the job was too big for him.

As for impeachment, that's a fairly traumatic process for the country and Congress probably wouldn't enter into it lightly. You are right that Congressional Republicans don't like Trump, but that doesn't mean they'll willingly take on the shame of removing one of their own from office. 

Having said that, I won't be surprised at all if Trump commits one or more impeachable offenses. The man's single-minded devotion to self-interest is bound to get him in trouble sooner or later. I'm just not sure it will matter to a Republican Congress eager to keep the White House.
